sentence: The Dow Jones Industrials Average is no dog, but constituent Dow Jones stocks Costco Wholesale Corporation (NASDAQ: COST ), Nike Inc (NYSE: NKE ) and Home Depot Inc (NYSE: HD ) are acting like technical mutts and ready for shorting.
Let me explain.
What's wrong with these Dow stocks?
Are investors in COST, NKE and HD, businesses which live and die by the consumer, betting these stocks will be among the first to feel the impact of tighter Federal Reserve policy?
As the market attempts to be a forward-looking instrument for the economy, it's certainly plausible.
And given this market mechanism, COST, NKE and HD investors may have additional reasons to be wary.
This Wednesday afternoon, the Fed will conclude its September FOMC meeting.
But will there be a rate hike?
Fed futures aren't betting on it as the chance for an increase is estimated at just 12%.

Considering how poorly the market has priced in monetary action this past year, the Brexit vote and even the likelihood of Trump being where he is today, these Dow Jones stocks are warning investors to get ahead of the curve.

â€¢ 8 International Stocks Priced to Beat the U.S.

Let's now take a closer technical look at COST, NKE and HD, as well as limited risk options strategies for each of these Dow Jones stocks so investors can position with limited risk and short these names more effectively, right now!
Click to Enlarge Dow Jones stock and wholesale behemoth Costco is in trouble!
Monetary policy aside, this strategist doesn't like the technical damage COST is showing on its daily price chart.
Shares of Costco have quickly moved from a favorable, high and tight or handle pattern while demonstrating relative strength, to a position of relative weakness over the past month.

Technically, COST is holding the 62% support level, but the sharp reversal lower (which has also lost the key, longer-term 50 and 200-day simple moving averages) implies not shopping until further dropping in this Dow Jones stock.
Checking the options board, the Oct $149/$145 for a dollar is attractive.

Earnings are in late September and this limited risk spread cuts down the risks associated with options Greeks while maintaining a catalyst to push shares lower and maximize the vertical's return potential of 300%.
Click to Enlarge Next up on our list of Dow Jones stocks to short is NKE.
You may love Nike's athletics gear, but investors have been running away from the company's shares in 2016 and there's still room for additional downside.
Currently, NKE is consolidating in a tight pennant or flag pattern.
Because the quiet price action follows a break below the 50-day MA, the ball is in the bears' court.
Reviewing the Nike options board, the Oct $54 put for $1.26 is a decent looking position for bears to consider.

As with Costco, NKE earnings are in late September, but the combination of a more mature bearish chart and affordable premiums have sparked our interest in a more offensive play with more open-ended returns afforded by the long put position.
Click to Enlarge Home Depot is the third of our Dow Jones stocks setting up as a short.
Of the three, HD stock has been the strongest.
However, technical deconstruction has definitely begun.
The provided weekly chart of HD shows a slanted triple top has received bearish confirmation with a more recent breakdown of Home Depot's uptrend line dating back to 2015's flash crash.
What's more, HD's technical failure has coincided with the stock penetrating its 200-day MA and moving into bear territory.
With Fibonacci support levels still well below current prices, it's time for bears to make a home in HD stock.
For an options strategy in this Dow Jones stock, the Oct $124/$120 bear put spread for 70 cents is interesting enough.
Unlike with COST and NKE, HD doesn't report until November.

Considering HD stock is the strongest of the three, approaching HD with a less costly, but still efficient vertical makes sense as a way to position as a limited risk bear in lieu of an earnings catalyst.
